item.title: Nintendo's Releasing A Game Boy Made Of Lego
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/lego-game-boy-price-release-date-tetris-nintendo-1851736436

Nintendo just announced a new console and it’s still not the Switch 2. The console maker is teaming up with Lego to release a Game Boy made of plastic bricks. It follows after a previous collaboration in which the two companies released a Lego NES together, complete with retro TV that displayed the first level of the original Super Mario Bros.

  • Off
  • English

Suggested Reading

Will the Lego Game Boy be an equally intricate homage to ‘80s gaming? Probably, but it’s hard to tell at the moment. All Nintendo released today when announcing the collaboration was a 15-second teaser and a release window of October 2025. Otherwise no price, no description, not even a glimpse of the finished product outside of the single D-pad brick.

The last Lego Nintendo system was the NES, which released in 2020. That set’s replica console, game cartridge, controller, and TV consisted of 2,646 bricks with a price tag of $200. I imagine the Game Boy set will be somewhat smaller and potentially cheaper as a result. After all, you can get an actual Nintendo Switch Lite that plays actual Game Boy games for $200.

Which raises another question. Will the Lego Game Boy play actual games? None of the other Lego consoles have, not the replica Atari 2600 and not the Pac-Man arcade machine. And actually running Tetris would require a screen, an emulation device of some kind, and a battery pack. So probably not.

Still, the Lego Game Boy is coming at the perfect moment to capitalize on retro handheld nostalgia. The Analogue Pocket continues to release tons of cool color variants and the ModRetro Chromatic, released just last year, has been getting good reviews and fueling fans’ Game Boy nostalgia (even if it was made by a company that wants to sell the government lethal AI-controlled drones).

item.title: The Best Thing In Marvel Rivals’ New Season Isn’t The Fantastic Four, It’s This Dog
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/marvel-rivals-bats-ghost-dog-doctor-strange-comic-map-1851736422

Marvel Rivals’ new season begins tomorrow, January 10, and there’s plenty to be excited about. Four new heroes are joining the roster, three maps are entering the rotation, and there’s a new battle pass of cosmetics. All that is well and good, but the most important addition to the game isn’t a new map, mode, or playable character. It’s a ghost dog who is hanging out in the hero shooter’s recreation of New York.

Blade’s Book Club Is The Best Thing About Marvel’s Midnight Suns

  • Off
  • English

Suggested Reading

Bats is, or…was a basset hound that Doctor Strange cared for. The ol’ dog was introduced in the 2017 Doctor Strange comics as the sorcerer’s pet. Strange cast an enchantment on Bats allowing him to communicate with people, but this was short-lived as the dog soon passed away due to a heart attack after a confrontation with Loki. Bats would later return to Strange’s side as a ghost, however, maintaining his speech capabilities and acting as the hero’s companion.

In the trailer for Marvel Rivals’ new season, which includes a map based on Doctor Strange’s base of operations, NetEase teased that Bats would make an appearance, and now that some players are exploring the inner halls of the Sanctum Santorum, it’s been revealed that Bat hangs out in the lobby.

I’m a casual Marvel fan and most of my exposure to its heroes comes from the MCU and video games, so I had no idea that Bats existed until recently. It seems like that’s the case for a lot of Rivals fans who are also finding out about the ghost dog’s existence through the shooter. Longtime comic fans are excited to see a more niche side of the Marvel universe represented. I just met Bats but I would die for him, and seeing so many fans share cute moments between him and Marvel heroes has endeared him to me real quick. Also, he’s a Spider-Man fanboy? NetEase, please put in some kind of interaction between the two if a Spidey player is in the room with him.

Marvel Rivals has a pretty expansive roster already, but within its maps and lore drops, it’s found ways to integrate other characters beyond the ones pushing payloads and capturing objectives. So thank you to NetEase for bringing Bats into my life. Let me pet him in the spawn room.

For more on Marvel Rivals, check out Kotaku’s review.
